sen.j: 令制国一覧 > 山陰道 > 丹後国
sen.e: List of provinces/San-indo./Tango Province
List of provinces/San-indo/Tango Province
List of provinces/San-indo/Tango Province

sen.j: 丹後国（たんごのくに）は、かつて日本の地方行政区分だった令制国の一つで、山陰道に位置する。
sen.e: Tango Province is one of the provinces administered by the 'ryo-sei' or administrative codes, and is located in San-indo.
Tango Province is one of the provinces administered by the 'ryo-sei' (administrative codes), and is located in San-indo.
Tango Province, located in Sanin-do, was one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei (administrative codes).

sen.j: 現在の京都府北部にあたる。
sen.e: The province matches the north part of the present-day Kyoto Prefecture.
The province corresponds to the northern part of present-day Kyoto Prefecture.
The province corresponds to the northern part of present-day Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 北丹や奥丹と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: It is also called Hokutan or Okutan.
It is also called Hokutan or Okutan.
It is also called Hokutan or Okutan.

sen.j: 延喜式での格は国司国等級区分、近国。
sen.e: The status of Engishiki is 'Kingoku' or nearby province in the criteria of Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun..
The status of Engishiki is 'Kingoku,' or a nearby province in the criteria of Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun..
Its status under the Engishiki (a book of laws and regulation compiled during the Engi era) was Kingoku, meaning near province, in the Kokushi-Kokutokyu-kubun category.
sen.cmt: スポットチェックを参考にしました。

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 古墳時代には竹野川流域を中心に繁栄しており、独自の王国が存在したとする説もある（丹後王国論を参照）。
sen.e: Some believe that during the Kofun period, the province prospered along the Takeno River and had its own kingdom (.See also Tango Kingdom Hypothesis)
sen.cmt: http://www.iris.dti.ne.jp/~muken/timei03.htm英辞郎 on the WEB定訳不明
sen.e: Some believe that during the Kofun period the province prospered along the Takeno River and had its own kingdom (see also "Tango Kingdom Hypothesis").
Some believe that during the Kofun period the province prospered along the Takeno-gawa River and had its own kingdom (see also "Tango Kingdom Hypothesis").

sen.j: 7世紀に令制国として丹波国が成立したときは、丹波郡（後の中郡）がその中心地であったと考えられる。
sen.e: Tamba-gun (later Naka-gun) is believed to have been the center of the kingdom when Tamba Province was established as one of the provinces administered by the ryo-sei in the seventh century.
Tamba-gun (later Naka-gun) is believed to have been the center of the kingdom when, in the seventh century, Tamba Province was established as one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei.
Tanba-gun (later Naka-gun) is believed to have been the center of the kingdom when, in the seventh century, Tamba Province was established as one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei.

sen.j: 和銅6年（713年）4月3日に丹波国の北部、加佐郡、与謝郡、丹波郡、竹野郡、熊野郡の5郡を割いて、丹後国が置かれた。
sen.e: Five districts of Kasa-gun, Yosa-gun, Tamba-gun, Takeno-gun, and Kumano-gun in the north of Tamba Province were separated from the province to form Tango Province on May 1, 713.
The five districts of Kasa-gun, Yosa-gun, Tamba-gun, Takeno-gun and Kumano-gun in the north of Tamba Province were separated from the province to form Tango Province on May 1, 713.
The five districts of Kasa-gun, Yosa-gun, Tamba-gun, Takeno-gun and Kumano-gun in the north of Tanba Province were separated from the province on April 3, 713, and thereby formed Tango Province.
sen.cmt: 日付修正 Tanba Proviceneとしました。

sen.j: 中世には足利氏の一族である一色氏が入封、一時期を除いて室町時代を通じて丹後一国を支配した。
sen.e: In the Medieval period, the Isshiki clan from the Ashikaga clan entered the domain, and governed the entire Tango Province throughout the Muromachi period, except for an interval.
In the Medieval period, the Isshiki clan from the Ashikaga clan entered the domain, whereupon the Isshiki governed the entire Tango Province throughout the Muromachi period, except for an interval.
In the middle ages, the Isshiki clan (a branch of the Ashikaga clan) entered the territory, after which they governed the entire Tango Province throughout almost all of the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: "throughout almost all of the Muromachi period" sounds much more natural than "throughout the Muromachi period, except for a short period of time."

sen.j: ただ、その支配体系は不明である。
sen.e: But their governance structures are unknown today.
However, their governance structures are unknown today.
However, their governance structures are unknown today.

sen.j: 恐らく、九州探題も務めたことのある一色氏自体は在京し、地元豪族を守護代として支配をしたのであろう。
sen.e: The Isshiki clan, who had served as Kyushu Tandai, would possibly have stayed in Kyoto and have appointed local powerful families as Shugodai to rule the province..
The Isshiki clan, which had served as Kyushu Tandai, would probably have stayed in Kyoto and appointed local powerful families as Shugodai to rule the province..

The Isshiki clan, which had served as Kyushu Tandai (regional officers to oversee the administration of Kyushu), would probably have stayed in Kyoto and appointed powerful local families as Shugodai to rule the province.
sen.cmt: 「九州探題」の補足として(regional officers to oversee the administration of Kyushu) と追加しました。

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)が始まる1498年には守護の一色義秀が地元豪族に攻められて自殺していることから、強力な施政はできなかったようにも思われる。
sen.e: From the fact that the Shugo 'Yoshihide ISSHIKI' was assaulted and driven into suicide by a local powerful family in 1498 around the onset of the Sengoku period, it seems the Isshiki clan did not have strong control over the province.

Based on the fact that the Shugo 'Yoshihide ISSHIKI' was assaulted and driven to suicide by a local powerful family in 1498 around the onset of the Sengoku period, it seems the Isshiki clan did not have strong control over the province.

Based on the fact that the Shugo Yoshihide ISSHIKI was assaulted and driven to suicide by a powerful local family in 1498 around the onset of the Sengoku (Warring States) period, apparently the Isshiki clan did not have strong control over the province.
sen.cmt: 戦国時代に (Warring States)と補足しました

sen.j: それでも一色氏の命脈は戦国期を通じて永らえたが、1579年7月に一色氏が細川幽斎に滅ぼされて以来、細川氏が丹後を支配した。
sen.e: Some of the Isshiki clan survived through the Sengoku period for a fairly long time, but in July 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA defeated the Isshiki clan and took over Tango Province afterward.
Some of the Isshiki clan survived through the Sengoku period for a fairly long time, but in July 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA defeated the Isshiki clan and thereafter took over Tango Province.
Some of the Isshiki clan survived through the Sengoku period for a fairly long time, but in July 1579 Yusai HOSOKAWA defeated the Isshiki clan and thereafter controlled Tango Province.

sen.j: 関ヶ原の戦い後、京極高知に、丹後守の称号と丹後一国、十二万三千石の領地が与えられ、国持ち大名京極家の領地となった。
sen.e: After the Battle of Sekigahara, Takatomo KYOGOKU was awarded the title of Tango no Kami and the entire Tango Province with the domain of 123,000 koku, and Tango Province became the territory of the land-owning daimyo the Kyogoku clan.

After the Battle of Sekigahara, Takatomo KYOGOKU was awarded the title of Tango no Kami, whereby all of Tango Province (a domain of 123,000 koku) and Tango Province became the territory of the land-owning daimyo, the Kyogoku clan.

After the Battle of Sekigahara, Takatomo KYOGOKU was awarded the title of Tango no Kami, whereby all of Tango Province (a domain of 123,000 koku) and Tango Province became the territory of the land-owning daimyo, the Kyogoku clan.

tit.e: Background of bunkoku (separation of the province)
tit.cmt: bunkoku (separation of the province)としました

sen.j: 丹波国が令制国として成立した当初には、丹波郡・丹波郷を有して丹波国の中心であったとみられる北部の地域が丹波国として残されず、逆に丹後国として分離されてしまったのは、丹波国の中心が北部の丹波郡から、より都に近い丹波国南部（丹後分国後の丹波国の地域）へと移動していたためと考えられている。
sen.e: The northern part of the region, seemingly the center including Tamba-gun and Tamba-go, was not included in Tamba Province, and was instead separated form Tango Province when Tamba Province was first established as one of the provinces administered by the ryo-sei; this could be explained by the assumption that the central area of Tamba Province had moved to the southern part of Tamba Province (a part of Tamba Province after the separation of Tango Province) from Tamba-gun in the north.

The northern part of the region, and seemingly the center (including Tamba-gun and Tamba-go), was not included in Tamba Province but was instead separated to form Tango Province when the former was first established as one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei; this could be explained by the assumption that the central area of Tamba Province had been incorporated into the southern part of Tamba Province (a part of Tamba Province after the separation of Tango Province) from Tamba-gun in the north.

The northern part of the region, and seemingly the center (including Tanba-gun and Tanba-go), was not included in Tanba Province but was instead separated to form Tango Province when the former was first established as one of the provinces administered by the Ryo-sei; this could be explained by the assumption that the central area of Tanba Province had been incorporated into the southern part of Tanba Province (a part of Tanba Province after the separation of Tango Province) from Tanba-gun in the north.

sen.j: 南部の桑田郡は国分寺・国分尼寺が建立され、奈良時代には丹波国の中心地となっていたことが知られる。
sen.e: Provincial monastery and nunnery were built in Kuwata-gun in the south, and during the Nara period, Kuwata-gun is known to have become the center of Tamba Province.
A provincial monastery and nunnery were built in Kuwata-gun in the south, and it is known that Kuwata-gun became the center of Tamba Province during the Nara period.
A provincial monastery and nunnery were built in Kuwata-gun in the south, and it is known that Kuwata-gun became the center of Tanba Province during the Nara period.

sen.j: また、分国後の丹波国が丹後国に対して「丹前国」とされなかったのは、分国当時（和銅6年）の分国の原則が、それ以前の同等な国の分割（吉備を備前、備中、備後とするような分割）とは異なり、母国から一部を割いて、分割された側に別の新国名を付ける形（備前から美作が分国するような形）がとられていた為であると考えられる。
sen.e: Additionally, the reason why Tamba Province after the separation was not named as 'Tanzen Province' after Tango Province would be because, unlike the previous principles of splitting a province evenly (e.g., the split of Kibi into Bizen, Bichu, and Bingo), in the principles used for its separation (713), a portion of the original province was separated and only the portion was given a new name (e.g., the separation of Mimasaka from Bizen).

Additionally, the reason that Tamba Province after the separation was not named 'Tanzen Province' after Tango Province would be that, unlike the previous principles of splitting a province evenly (e.g., the split of Kibi into Bizen, Bichu and Bingo), in the principles used for its separation (713) a portion of the original province was separated and only the portion was given a new name (e.g., the separation of Mimasaka from Bizen).

Additionally, the reason that Tanba Province after the separation was not named 'Tanzen Province' after Tango Province would be that, unlike the previous principles of splitting a province evenly (e.g., the split of Kibi into Bizen, Bichu and Bingo), in the principles used for its separation (713) a portion of the original province was separated and only the portion was given a new name (e.g., the separation of Mimasaka from Bizen).
sen.cmt: この文章は、漢字が理解できないと理解が難しいと思うのですが（丹後、丹前など）、左記の文章でネイティブの方は理解できますでしょうか？すみませんが、NCをお願いいたします。

sen.j: そして分割された側でありながら、丹後（二字で「タニハノミチノシリ」と訓じられた）とされて新たな国名が与えられなかったのは、ここが元々の丹波の地であるので、タニハノミチノシリとして「タニハ」の名を残した為とみられる。
sen.e: It is also believed that because the region was originally in Tango, a new province name was not given and the name Tamba (pronounced as 'Tanihanomichinoshiri) was kept to have the word 'Taniha' in it, despite being separated from Tamba Province.

It is also believed that because the region was originally in Tango a new provincial name was not given and the name Tamba (pronounced as 'Tanihanomichinoshiri) was kept in order to have the word 'Taniha' in it, despite being separated from Tamba Province.

It is also believed that, despite being separated from Tanba Province, the name Tango (pronounced as 'Tanihanomichinoshiri') was kept and a new provincial name was not given, because the region was originally in Tanba and the word 'Taniha' was intentionally kept as "Tanihanomichinoshiri."
sen.cmt: 左記の文章も、チェックをお願いします。

sen.j: 国府、一宮など
sen.e: Ancient provincial offices, Ichinomiya, and so forth
Ancient provincial offices, Ichinomiya, etc.
Ancient provincial offices, Ichinomiya, etc.

sen.j: 国府は、和名類聚抄および拾芥抄では、加佐郡。
sen.e: The Wamyoruiju-sho and the Shugai-sho indicate that ancient provincial offices were in Kasa-gun
The Wamyoruiju-sho and Shugai-sho indicate that ancient provincial offices were located in Kasa-gun.
The Wamyoruiju-sho and Shugai-sho indicate that ancient provincial offices were located in Kasa-gun.

sen.j: 現在の舞鶴市内と思われる。
sen.e: They would have probably been in present-day Maizuru City.
They would probably have been in what is now Maizuru City.
They would probably have been in what is now Maizuru City.

sen.j: ただし、易林本の節用集では、与謝郡とある。
sen.e: In the Setsu-yo-shu derived from the Ekirin-bon, however, the offices are described as being in Yosa-gun,.
In the Setsu-yo-shu derived from the Ekirin-bon, but the offices are described as being in Yosa-gun.
However, in the Setsu-yo-shu derived from the Ekirin-bon, the offices are described as being in Yosa-gun.

sen.j: 現在の宮津市府中と推定される。
sen.e: It is assumed that the offices were in Fuchu Miyazu City.
It is assumed that the offices were in Fuchu Miyazu City.
It is assumed that the offices were in Fuchu, Miyazu City.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には大社7座6社・小社58座58社の計65座64社が記載されている。
sen.e: The Engi Shiki Jimmyo-Cho contains information on 7 gods and 6 grand shrines, and 58 gods and 58 small shrines, totaling 65 gods and 64 shrines.
The Engi Shiki Jimmyo-Cho contains information on seven gods and six grand shrines, as well as 58 gods and 58 small shrines, thus totaling 65 gods and 64 shrines.
The Engishiki Jimmyo-Cho (a list of shrines) contains information on seven gods and six grand shrines, as well as 58 gods and 58 small shrines, thus totaling 65 gods and 64 shrines.
sen.cmt: 神名帳の補足として (a list of shrines)と追加しました。

sen.j: 大社6社は以下の通りで、竹野神社以外は名神大社に列している。
sen.e: The six grand shrines are below and the five of them except Takeno-jinja Shrine belong to Myojin-taisha Shrine.
The six grand shrines are listed below, and five of them (excluding Takeno-jinja Shrine) belong to Myojin-taisha Shrine.
The six grand shrines are listed below, and five of them (excluding Takeno-jinja Shrine) belong to Myojin-taisha Shrine:

sen.e: Okawa-jinja Shrine in Kasa-gun (Maizuru City)

Kono-jinja Shrine in Yosa-gun (Miyazu City)

sen.j: 一宮は籠神社であり、二宮は大宮売神社とされている。
sen.e: It is believed that the first shrine is Kono-jinja Shrine, and the second one is Omiyame-jinja Shrine.
It is believed that the first shrine was Kono-jinja Shrine and the second was Omiyame-jinja Shrine.
It is believed that the Ichinomiya (first shrine) was Kono-jinja Shrine and the Ninomiya (second shrine) was Omiyame-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 総社は不詳であるが、籠神社が総社を兼ねていたとする説もある。
sen.e: It is not clear which shrine is the sosha -- a shrine enshrining several gods of the shrines in the region, but some believe that Kono-jinja Shrine could be the sosha as well.
It is not clear which shrine is the sosha--a shrine enshrining several gods of the shrines in the region--but some believe that Kono-jinja Shrine could be the sosha as well.
It is not clear which shrine is the sosha--one enshrining several gods of the shrines in the region--but some believe that Kono-jinja Shrine could have been the sosha as well.
